title: 07. Rhetoric in Athens
description: The role of rhetoric in Athenian political and legal decision-making during the classical period.

questions.question: Why was rhetoric especially important in the Athenian assembly?
options: Decisions depended on persuasion rather than expertise
Only elites were allowed to speak

questions.question: Which statesman used rhetoric to secure the ostracism of Thucydides son of Melesias?
Which source describes Pericles’ rhetorical dominance over the people?
How does Cleon attempt to influence the Assembly in the Mytilene Debate?
options: By using aggressive and emotional rhetoric

questions.question: Why was Cleon unsuccessful in the second Mytilene debate?
Which historian records the speeches of Cleon and Diodotus?
How does Aristophanes portray Cleon in his comedies?
Which plays heavily criticise Cleon’s rhetorical influence?
Which individual does Aristophanes mock as a demagogue alongside Cleon?
Who persuaded the Athenians to launch the Sicilian Expedition?
What consequence followed Alcibiades’ rhetorical success?
Which source emphasises Alcibiades’ persuasive influence over the people?
How did Nicias and Alcibiades remove Hyperbolus from politics?
options: By combining rhetoric to secure his ostracism

questions.question: Who dominated the Assembly near the end of the Peloponnesian War?
Why did Cleophon’s rhetoric obstruct peace?
options: He persuaded the demos to reject compromise

questions.question: Why was rhetoric especially important in the law courts?
options: Citizens had to speak for themselves

questions.question: What claim does Socrates make about his own speaking ability in the Apology?
options: That he is poor at rhetoric
That he is a skilled orator

questions.question: Why is Socrates’ claim ironic?
options: The speech itself is highly rhetorical
